data.text: The soil and agriculture
The agriculture of a country depends on the kind of soil and rocks that are found there.
Agriculture is possible only in those places where there is fertile soil and enough water.
In mountainous regions, agriculture is not possible as there is snow on the ground for most of the year and the land is rocky.
In the river valleys between mountains and in the river plains, the soil is usually fertile.
People settle in these valleys and plains to practise agriculture.
Deserts are sandy and water is scarce, so it is difficult to grow crops.
By building canals, desert areas can also be made fertile.
Alluvial soil is the most fertile soil. It is found in the plains around rivers.
Fast flowing rivers in the mountains break up the rocks and cut through the earth. This is called erosion.
Soil loses fertility during heavy showers as the fast-flowing water carries away much of the soil at the surface and exposes the rocks beneath.
Planting trees helps to protect the topsoil as the roots hold soil particles together.
Punjab and Sindh are the major agricultural regions of Pakistan.
Punjab and Sindh have the largest network of canals which helps in irrigation.
In mountainous regions, farmers practise terrace farming by making fields on the mountain slopes.
